awd_titl_txt: NebraskaSCIENCE: A School-University Partnership to Develop Exemplary Science Teachers in Nebraska
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO) will undertake a Noyce Track 1 project to recruit, prepare, and support a minimum of 25 undergraduate majors in the disciplines of biology, chemistry, geography/geology, and physics to become well-prepared secondary school science teachers. Project activities will develop culturally responsive science teachers with deep STEM content expertise through the use of specific pedagogies.  It will actively involve the Noyce Scholars in the process of science so that they can engage youth from diverse backgrounds in the scientific enterprise. Noyce Scholars will participate in professional development activities from inception through their early years of teaching in high-need school districts. 

The project will build upon ongoing collaborative efforts between UNO and the Omaha Public Schools (OPS) that expand and strengthen the pathways that prepare science majors to meet the demand for science teachers in high-need school districts. Project activities will guide students through Bachelor of Science degrees, including secondary teacher certification. The project will provide structured internships for first- and second-year STEM undergraduates to gain experience working with students from high-need schools in OPS; provide financial, academic, and professional leadership development support for third- and fourth-year STEM undergraduates to prepare them for teaching in high-need school districts; and provide ongoing professional development support for Noyce Scholars alumni in secondary school classrooms.  This Noyce project will use a systematic evaluation plan that continuously measures the overall impact of its initiatives and provides formative feedback on the effectiveness of key strategies so that refinements can be made over the five-year grant period.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The NoyceSCIENCE program has created, implemented, led, and mentored the first Science Teacher Noyce Track 1 award at the University of Nebraska at Omaha (UNO) since 2017. This project builds upon ongoing collaborative efforts between the UNO and the Omaha public school system (OPS) to strengthen and expand the pipeline for preparing highly qualified science teachers at UNO to better meet the high demand for STEM teachers in local school districts, particularly those districts with high need schools, such as OPS. We aimed to attract, retain, and empower a diverse workforce. Throughout this project our specific objectives were to: 1) provide structured internships in which first- and second-year undergraduates (Noyce Interns) gain experience working with students from high need schools in OPS; 2) provide financial, academic, and professional development support for third- and fourth-year undergraduates (Noyce Scholars) to prepare them for teaching in high need schools; and 3) provide ongoing professional development support for former Noyce Scholars (Noyce Teachers).

Project outcomes include:

  • Program provided financial, academic, and professional support for both Noyce Interns (11 students) and Noyce Scholars (16 students). The students in the program have participated in numerous research-based projects and have presented their work both regionally and nationally. Students participated in professional development series which included culturally relevant pedagogy, building agency in learners, as well as content-specific contributions from subject-matter experts, as well as public school district level staff to share more about teaching as a profession. Additionally, opportunities were provided for students to work with faculty members as learning assistant in the course-based undergraduate research courses and participated as leaders through outreach programs designed for elementary and middle school students in STEM in the surrounding Omaha public school district.
  • We generated dual pathway opportunities for students to complete degrees in content area (i.e. Biology, Chemistry, Geology/Geography, Environmental Science, and Physics) as well as with a teaching endorsement through pedagogical course completion to be certified to teach grades 7-12 science. This included alignment between two colleges, as well as across the individual programs listed above, coupled with the Teacher Education Department. Given the various ethos of the Departments involved, and the inter-campus collaboration required across so many content areas, this was a major success story in direct support of students, particularly to provide high-quality teachers who are masters of their subject matter to 1) provide instruction in high-needs schools, and 2) to enable the teachers, once in the field, to continue their studies toward MS or other advanced degree to continue their content depth as well as be able to move up the pay scale.
  • We worked to reduce the course barriers to becoming a certified teacher. We reviewed and updated the state-mandated course requirements (i.e. Rule 24 matrices) for teacher certification in Nebraska and reduced requirements for pre-service teachers to better align with NGSS state and national standards and required skillsets. Thus, streamlining the degree roadmaps and ultimately expedited the time to degree for our dual-pathway or content with certification teachers. The new roadmaps are a 4.5-year degree, thus reducing the time to degree by nearly 2 years. This reduction of coursework helps students in the sciences to graduate faster, likely to be retained even better.

 

The NebraskaSCIENCE project supported majors as they identify teaching as a passion area, and support them via by providing them mentorship, professional development, and networks to implement social capital to best support their development. Noyce Interns and Scholars gained direct mentorship by faculty, a near peer support system, informal and formal teaching opportunities, and research experiences. Future UNO students will benefit from the formed pathways for dual-degrees and content-based teacher certification, established roadmaps for these new pathways for students across each of the science areas (i.e. biology, chemistry, geology, and physics), and with the reduction of coursework to allow them to graduate faster as certified and well-trained teachers.


Last Modified: 08/24/2024
Modified by: John A Conrad
